how come it isn't exact match?

Why is it 2 when line 132 talks about 8 byte codes?

A complete postcode size are 8 bytes which combined `code` and `index` from 4 ports, so pccSize from each port is 2 bytes.

The postcode raw format as below (port index: 0x40 - 0x43)
[P0_CODE][P0_INDEX][P1_CODE][P1_INDEX][P2_CODE][P2_INDEX][P3_CODE][P3_INDEX]

```
root@bmc-oob:~# hexdump -C /dev/aspeed-lpc-pcc 
00000000  a0 40 00 41 00 42 ee 43  a3 40 00 41 00 42 ee 43  |.@.A.B.C.@.A.B.C|
00000010  a2 40 00 41 00 42 ee 43  a2 40 00 41 00 42 ee 43  |.@.A.B.C.@.A.B.C|
......
```

Can we get some more comments to this effect in the code then?  You can't expect everyone reviewing to be intimately familiar with this particular hardware detail.  "2 bytes per code" doesn't tell me much.
Acknowledged
What are these patterns and where do they come from?

The postcode raw format as below (port index: 0x40 - 0x43)
[P0_CODE][P0_INDEX][P1_CODE][P1_INDEX][P2_CODE][P2_INDEX][P3_CODE][P3_INDEX]

- 0x43pp42qq41rr40ss
This is a example for a complete postcode (8 bytes).


- 0x41rr40ss
This is a example for the incomplete postcode (4 bytes).
This const does nothing useful.
This part is not exist in PS4, so resolved for now.
codeSize*pccSize?  codeSize is currently 1, so we only look at a single byte?

The codeSize can be updated by passing `-b ${post-code-bytes}`
For aspeed-lpc-pcc device we will require "post-code-bytes = 8"

index = prefix == pccPrefixBase;

I think it would be better to not embed a machine-specific concept right into the middle of this code.  Make a std::function that can be used for processing post codes.  Assign the std::function to processPCC in the case on line 325.
add `std::function<int(uint64_t&, ssize_t)> procPostCode`

does
```
optarg == "aspeed-lpc-pcc"
```
work?
The type of `optarg` is `char *`, so it will have compile error in this case.

Hi reviewers, Sorry for taking long time to submit new patchset.
I rewrite entire function and use a `std::vector<uint16_t> aspeedPccBuffer` for storing the PCC codes, also simplify the PCC code check mechanism base on the vector size.
I hope this new mechanism is more simple and readable. Please kindly help me review this new code, thank you.

Suggest a comment to indicate that this is the size of data coming from the `PCC` hardware, not the post codes themselves.  As you have in the comment on line 133, I think I understand this better now, but this being the first aspect of the design in code, it seems likely to be misinterpreted.

I suggest moving this into the `aspeedPcc` function directly.  There appears to be no usage of it outside of that function.
move into aspeedPCC().
Acknowledged
Does this work for what you're tryingto accomplish?  Aren't you trying to support 4 byte post codes.

The codeSize will be reassigned by input args (line 296 - 309).
User can config it by adding `POST_CODE_BYTES = "8"` in bbappened file.

I hope this answers your question.
Acknowledged
Why are we creating a global to hold this?

nit: `aspeedPCCBuffer` (adjust use of PCC everywhere).

PCC is an acronym.  The project policy is that acronyms should be either all lowercase or all uppercase and not a mixture.
got it, check entire file and fix it.
move into aspeedPCC().

I'm very concerned about the fragility of this code.  Aren't there endianness issues?  How do you know the "good data" will be in the upper bytes of a uint64 if only 2 or 4 bytes were read from hardware?

This is reason I use aspeedPCCBuffer for storing each PCC code.

1. receieve 4 bytes data `[0x40AA][0x41BB]`

  - aspeedPCCBuffer[0] = 0x40AA
  - aspeedPCCBuffer[1] = 0x41BB

`aspeedPCCBuffer.size()` less than `fullPostPCCCount`, it means aspeedPCCBuffer does not have enough data for 1 full postcode. return and wait for next coming data.


2. receieve 8 bytes data `[0x42CC][0x43DD][0x40EE][0x41FF]`

  - aspeedPCCBuffer[0] = 0x40AA
  - aspeedPCCBuffer[1] = 0x41BB
  - aspeedPCCBuffer[2] = 0x42CC
  - aspeedPCCBuffer[3] = 0x43DD
  - aspeedPCCBuffer[4] = 0x40EE
  - aspeedPCCBuffer[5] = 0x41FF

`aspeedPCCBuffer.size()` bigger than `fullPostPCCCount` now, it means aspeedPCCBuffer contains 1 full postcode, start postcode preparation.
After process, the remaining aspeedPCCBuffer as below
  - aspeedPCCBuffer[0] = 0x40EE
  - aspeedPCCBuffer[1] = 0x41FF

And return the postcode as `0xDDCCBBAA`
Acknowledged

Isn't 4 only used for 4 byte post codes and doesn't work for 1 or 2 byte post codes?  This implies that the code is only useful for 4 byte post codes, which I don't think we should push that limitation.
got it, I think I should use fullPostPCCCount instead.

Patch looks similar to https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-host-postd/+/56974.
See Andrew J comment on Aspeed PCC driver support OpenBMC kernel related.

can we remove this loop and replace with something like,
((code & 0x00FF000000000000) >> 48) | ((code & 0x000000FF00000000) >> 32) |
((code & 0x0000000000FF0000) >> 16) | ((code & 0x00000000000000FF) >> 0)

Why?  Is one more readable than the other?  


Optimization is not a valid reason because the compiler should unwind this for-loop as its bounds are known at compile-time.  (Experiment with godbolt.org if you'd like to confirm).
Acknowledged
